name: Förskolan Hoppet
subtitle: Sweden's first fossil-free preschool with 62% CO2 reduction

executive_summary.headline: 62% CO2 reduction through bio-based materials and circular construction - Sweden's pioneering fossil-free preschool
key_achievements: 62% CO2 reduction compared to reference preschool (206 vs 543 kg CO2e/m² BTA)
First Swedish preschool combining multiple circular strategies (timber, reuse, recycled foundation)
NollCO2 pilot project - Sweden Green Building Council
Koljern recycled glass foundation (60-70% recycled content, 50% CO2 reduction vs concrete)
CLT structure from local Södra production within 60km
Reused acoustic panels via Ecophon SoundCircularity service
Reused bricks, glass blocks, concrete pavers from local demolition
Hemp-lime and wood fiber insulation replacing fossil-based alternatives
executive_summary.why_flagship: Förskolan Hoppet is Sweden's first fossil-free preschool and demonstrates that combining bio-based materials with targeted reuse can achieve dramatic CO2 reductions. The project served as NollCO2 pilot and established methodologies for fossil-free public construction.
executive_summary.why_tier: Completeness score 85/100 (Grade A). Comprehensive LCA documentation from Gothenburg City with verified CO2 metrics across all A1-A5 phases.

budget.cost_assessment: Bio-based materials required new supply chain development but achieved competitive costs at scale

design_approach.key_insight: Fossil-free and material reuse are complementary but distinct strategies
design_approach.main_building: Achieving 62% CO2 reduction required prioritizing bio-based materials over reuse
design_approach.auxiliary_buildings: Provided safe testing ground for reuse without risking main building timeline

success_factors: Early commitment to fossil-free goal from municipality
Willingness to test reuse in auxiliary buildings
NollCO2 pilot status provided methodology and visibility
challenges_encountered: Bio-based insulation materials less established in Swedish market
Reuse requires flexibility in design to accommodate available materials
LCA documentation more complex for mixed new/reused materials
recommendations: Separate fossil-free goals from material reuse goals - both valuable but different approaches
Use auxiliary structures to test reuse without timeline risk
Develop local bio-based supply chains for cost competitiveness
Manufacturer take-back programs (like Ecophon) reduce reuse complexity

replicability_assessment.scalability: High - bio-based strategies scale well; NollCO2 methodology being adopted across Sweden

narrative.driver: Gothenburg City's goal to demonstrate fossil-free construction. First project to eliminate fossil-based materials (plastic, concrete, steel) in favor of bio-based alternatives.
narrative.approach: Main building uses innovative bio-based materials (CLT, hemp-lime, wood fiber). Auxiliary buildings served as test lab for direct reuse (brick, glass blocks, clay from opera). Foundation replaced concrete with recycled glass cellular foam (Koljern system).
narrative.significance: Established template for fossil-free public building construction in Sweden. Demonstrated 62% CO2 reduction is achievable with available technology and supply chains.
narrative.legacy: NollCO2 pilot project methodology now being applied to other Swedish public buildings.
